What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A good understanding of many topics in wireless and IoT. Linux, MATLAB skills, and general familiarity with computer systems.

Learned a lot about different types of wireless technologies such as the Internet, internet protocols, communicating between devices on a wireless network; we also touched on Zigbee, RFID, Bluetooth, and lesser-known wireless technologies. We had 7 in-person labs and learned a lot about how the internet works, and our Final Project allowed us to be creative in applying what we learned in an IoT project.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The most interesting (yet difficult) part of the course was the labs. I learned skills that would be very useful for me in the future and using the command line, and connecting between devices on a network.

Weaknesses: Professor Hu is an intelligent and knowledgeable instructor, but flies by a lot of material too fast.
Also, the labs did NOT fit into two hours, especially for the non-grad students. It's probably better to 1) either shorten the labs or 2) advertise the labs as 3 hours; and have people who finish them quickly just leave early.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live lectures and in-person labs (with COVID protocols) was pretty useful for our given Yale COVID restrictions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this! Especially to EE majors looking to find an elective. This is one of the most hands on courses in the department. The final project gives you a chance to develop your own project, time manage, and explore more what interests you. The labs were also fun and well designed so that everyone of any skill level could learn. By far my favorite EE class to date!
Definitely, if you're interested in wireless and IoT. This is a comprehensive intro to many topics, it's content-rich and well-planned, and the workload is very reasonable.
Yes, if you are interested in the basics behind how wireless technologies and the internet works, please take this class! The lectures are dry, but the labs are engaging and interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
- recorded lecture
- live virtual lecture
- in-person lab
Live lectures were recorded for future viewing. Plus, in-person labs.
